o	The Stationary Source has well-established practices and procedures to maintain pressure vessels, piping systems, relief and vent systems, controls, pumps and compressors, and emergency shutdown systems in a safe operating condition.
o	The Stationary Source promptly investigates all incidents that resulted in, or reasonably could have resulted in, a fire/explosion, toxic gas release, major property damage, environmental loss, or personal injury to determine the facts and develop corrective actions to prevent a recurrence of the incident or a similar incident.

Consequences Minimization Measures following Accidental Release	
o	Fire suppression and extinguishing equipment
o	Personal Protective Equipment
o	Safety features installed in Stationary Source: including but not limited to, process relief valves, isolation valves (manual or automated), curbing or diking to contain liquid releases and atmospheric relief valves

Source is not designated as a first responder in case of an accidental release of a regulated substance. The Stationary Source maintains a written emergency response program, which is in place to protect worker and public safety as well as the environment. The program consists of procedures for responding to a release of a regulated substance, including the possibility of a fire or explosion if a flammable substance is accidently released. If Stationary Source employees take part in responding to accidental releases, then the Stationary Source is required to periodically review and update, as appropriate, the Stationary Sources emergency response program and notify employees of any changes to the emergency response plan (40 CFR 68.95). Updates should include the date of the most recent review of the emergency response program and most recent training. The Stationary Source is also expected to contact the Local Emergency Planning Committee to verify whether the Stationary Source is currently included in the community emergency response plan. Section 9 of the CDX RMP Submit Document (Appendix 4) provides updated information (including dates and other pertinent details) that was reviewed by the Stationary Source to ensure that the procedures for the emergency response program have been updated and verified.

Accident Prevention Measures	
o	The Stationary Source encourages employees to participate in all facets of process safety management and accident prevention.
o	The Stationary Source retains a variety of technical documents that are used to help maintain safe operation of the processes.
o	The Stationary Source has procedures in place to ensure that contractors perf

The Energy Transfer  Cedar Bayou Tank Farm (herinafter referred to as Stationary Source) will be a Program 1 process under the ARP Program based on the following criteria:
	The Stationary Source stores greater than the threshold quantities of regulated substances,
	A worst case release of a regulated substance would affect public receptors, and
	It is a manned Stationary Source that is subject to OSHA PSM regulation.

This report documents the steps taken to determine the program applicability and develop the Risk Management Plan (RMP) for the Stationary Source. These steps include:
	Verification of program applicability;
	Verification of chemical quantities in each process and largest vessel quantity;
	Completion of the off site consequence analysis and impacts; and
	Update of the five year accident history

ACCIDENT HISTORY
According to 40 CFR 68.42, The owner or operator shall include in the five-year accident. 
history all accidental releases from covered processes that resulted in deaths, injuries, or significant property damage onsite, or known offsite deaths, injuries, evacuations, sheltering in place, property damage, or environmental damage.
The Stationary Source has not had any accidental releases during the past five years that meet the criteria for an accidental release as discussed in 40 CFR 68.42.

VERIFICATION OF PROCESS INFORMATION
Facilities have an ongoing responsibility to monitor whether changes to any process or to the quantities stored or handled alter the Stationary Sources program level eligibility. A 5-year renewal also gives the Stationary Source personnel the opportunity to verify that each covered process still meets the eligibility criteria for its program level. Based on information regarding the type and quantity of stored/handled chemicals currently onsite, it was verified that the Stationary Source process areas are Program 1 processes under the ARP Program (40 CFR 68).
